CellValue_English: Operating leases
CellFormula_English: 'Operating leases

CellValue_English: Lease payments from operating leases are recognised as income on either a straight-line basis or another systematic basis. Another systematic basis is applied if that basis is more representative of the pattern in which benefit from the use of the underlying asset is diminished.
CellFormula_English: 'Lease payments from operating leases are recognised as income on either a straight-line basis or another systematic basis. Another systematic basis is applied if that basis is more representative of the pattern in which benefit from the use of the underlying asset is diminished.

CellValue_English: Costs, including depreciation, incurred in earning the lease income is recognised as an expense.
CellFormula_English: 'Costs, including depreciation, incurred in earning the lease income is recognised as an expense.

CellValue_English: Initial direct costs incurred in obtaining an operating lease are added to the carrying amount of the underlying asset and those costs are recognised as an expense over the lease term on the same basis as the lease income.
CellFormula_English: 'Initial direct costs incurred in obtaining an operating lease are added to the carrying amount of the underlying asset and those costs are recognised as an expense over the lease term on the same basis as the lease income.

CellValue_English: Depreciation and impairment is calculated and recognised on the underlying asset in accordance with the relevant policy for the class of underlying asset.
CellFormula_English: '="The carrying amount of the asset is reduced through the use of an allowance account, and the amount of the loss is recognised in "&PSLower&" or "&LDLower&" within operating expenses. When levies in arrears are uncollectible, it is written off against the allowance account. "&"Subsequent recoveries of amounts previously written off are credited against operating expenses in "&PSLower&" or "&LDLower&"."

CellValue_English: A manufacturer or dealer lessor does not recognise any selling profit on entering into an operating lease because it is not the equivalent of a sale.
CellFormula_English: 'A manufacturer or dealer lessor does not recognise any selling profit on entering into an operating lease because it is not the equivalent of a sale.

CellValue_English: Lease modifications
CellFormula_English: 'Lease modifications

CellValue_English: Modifications to an operating lease are accounted for as a new lease from the effective date of the modification, considering any prepaid or accrued lease payments relating to the original lease as part of the lease payments for the new lease.
CellFormula_English: 'Modifications to an operating lease are accounted for as a new lease from the effective date of the modification, considering any prepaid or accrued lease payments relating to the original lease as part of the lease payments for the new lease.

CellValue_English: Provisions and contingencies
CellFormula_English: 'Provisions and contingencies

CellValue_English: A provision is a liability of uncertain timing or amount. A liability is a present obligation of the entity arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow from the entity of resources embodying economic benefits.
CellFormula_English: 'A provision is a liability of uncertain timing or amount. A liability is a present obligation of the entity arising from past events, the settlement of which is expected to result in an outflow from the entity of resources embodying economic benefits.

CellValue_English: A contingent liability is:
CellFormula_English: 'A contingent liability is:

CellValue_English: A contingent asset is a possible asset that arises from past events and whose existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within the control of the entity.
CellFormula_English: 'A contingent asset is a possible asset that arises from past events and whose existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within the control of the entity.

CellValue_English: A provision is recognised when:
CellFormula_English: 'A provision is recognised when:

CellValue_English: The amount recognised as a provision is the best estimate of the expenditure required to settle the present obligation at the end of the reporting period. Where the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of a provision is the present value of the expenditures expected to be required to settle the obligation.
CellFormula_English: 'The amount recognised as a provision is the best estimate of the expenditure required to settle the present obligation at the end of the reporting period. Where the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of a provision is the present value of the expenditures expected to be required to settle the obligation.

CellValue_English: Where some or all of the expenditure required to settle a provision is expected to be reimbursed by another party, the reimbursement is recognised when it is virtually certain that reimbursement will be received when the obligation is settled. The reimbursement is treated as a separate asset. The amount recognised for the reimbursement will not exceed the amount of the provision.
CellFormula_English: 'Where some or all of the expenditure required to settle a provision is expected to be reimbursed by another party, the reimbursement is recognised when it is virtually certain that reimbursement will be received when the obligation is settled. The reimbursement is treated as a separate asset. The amount recognised for the reimbursement will not exceed the amount of the provision.

CellValue_English: Provisions are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted to reflect the current best estimate. If it is no longer probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation, the provision is reversed.
CellFormula_English: 'Provisions are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted to reflect the current best estimate. If it is no longer probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation, the provision is reversed.

CellValue_English: A provision is used only for expenditures for which the provision was originally recognised.
CellFormula_English: 'A provision is used only for expenditures for which the provision was originally recognised.

CellValue_English: Provisions are not recognised for future operating losses.
CellFormula_English: 'Provisions are not recognised for future operating losses.

CellValue_English: The present obligation under an onerous contract is recognised and measured as a provision.
CellFormula_English: 'The present obligation under an onerous contract is recognised and measured as a provision.

CellValue_English: A constructive obligation to restructure arises only when:
CellFormula_English: 'A constructive obligation to restructure arises only when:

CellValue_English: After initial recognition and until the liability is settled, cancelled or expires, a contingent liability is recognised in a business combination at the higher of the amount that would be recognised as a provision, and the amount initially recognised less cumulative amortisation.
CellFormula_English: 'After initial recognition and until the liability is settled, cancelled or expires, a contingent liability is recognised in a business combination at the higher of the amount that would be recognised as a provision, and the amount initially recognised less cumulative amortisation.

CellValue_English: Contingent assets and liabilities are not recognised, but details are disclosed in the notes to the financial statements.
CellFormula_English: 'Contingent assets and liabilities are not recognised, but details are disclosed in the notes to the financial statements.

CellValue_English: Share-based payments
CellFormula_English: 'Share-based payments

CellValue_English: Goods or services received or acquired in a share-based payment transaction are recognised when the goods are obtained or as the services are received. A corresponding increase in equity is recognised if the goods or services were received in an equity-settled share-based payment transaction, or a liability if the goods or services were acquired in a cash-settled share-based payment transaction.
CellFormula_English: 'Goods or services received or acquired in a share-based payment transaction are recognised when the goods are obtained or as the services are received. A corresponding increase in equity is recognised if the goods or services were received in an equity-settled share-based payment transaction, or a liability if the goods or services were acquired in a cash-settled share-based payment transaction.

CellValue_English: When the goods or services received or acquired in a share-based payment transaction do not qualify for recognition as assets, they are recognised as expenses.
CellFormula_English: 'When the goods or services received or acquired in a share-based payment transaction do not qualify for recognition as assets, they are recognised as expenses.

CellValue_English: For equity-settled share-based payment transactions, the goods or services received and the corresponding increase in equity is measured directly, at the fair value of the goods or services received, unless that fair value cannot be estimated reliably. If the fair value cannot be estimate reliably, their value, and the corresponding increase in equity is measured indirectly, by reference to the fair value of the equity instruments granted.
CellFormula_English: 'For equity-settled share-based payment transactions, the goods or services received and the corresponding increase in equity is measured directly, at the fair value of the goods or services received, unless that fair value cannot be estimated reliably. If the fair value cannot be estimate reliably, their value, and the corresponding increase in equity is measured indirectly, by reference to the fair value of the equity instruments granted.

CellValue_English: For cash-settled share-based payment transactions, the goods or services acquired and the liability incurred is measured at the fair value of the liability. Until the liability is settled, the fair value of the liability is remeasured at the end of each reporting period and at the date of settlement, with any changes in fair value recognised in profit or loss for the period.
CellFormula_English: 'For cash-settled share-based payment transactions, the goods or services acquired and the liability incurred is measured at the fair value of the liability. Until the liability is settled, the fair value of the liability is remeasured at the end of each reporting period and at the date of settlement, with any changes in fair value recognised in profit or loss for the period.

CellValue_English: For share-based payment transactions in which the terms of the arrangement provide either the entity or the counterparty with the choice of whether the settlement of the transaction is in cash or by issuing equity instruments, transaction, or the components of that transaction, are accounted for as a cash-settled share-based payment transaction if, and to the extent that a liability has been incurred to settle in cash or other assets, or as an equity-settled share-based payment transaction if, and to the extent that, no such liability has been incurred.
CellFormula_English: 'For share-based payment transactions in which the terms of the arrangement provide either the entity or the counterparty with the choice of whether the settlement of the transaction is in cash or by issuing equity instruments, transaction, or the components of that transaction, are accounted for as a cash-settled share-based payment transaction if, and to the extent that a liability has been incurred to settle in cash or other assets, or as an equity-settled share-based payment transaction if, and to the extent that, no such liability has been incurred.

CellValue_English: Revenue from contracts with customers
CellFormula_English: 'Revenue from contracts with customers

CellValue_English: Revenue is income arising in the course of an entity's ordinary activities.
CellFormula_English: 'Revenue is income arising in the course of an entity's ordinary activities.

CellValue_English: At the inception of a contract, the goods or services promised in the contract are assessed and a performance obligation is identified for each promise to transfer to the customer either:

CellValue_English: Revenue is is recognised when or as the performance obligation is satisfied by transferring a promised good or service to a customer. Assets are transferred when or as the customer obtains control of that asset.
CellFormula_English: 'Revenue is is recognised when or as the performance obligation is satisfied by transferring a promised good or service to a customer. Assets are transferred when or as the customer obtains control of that asset.

CellValue_English: Measurement
CellFormula_English: 'Measurement

CellValue_English: When a performance obligation is satisfied, revenue is recognised as the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the performance obligation, but excluding estimates of variable consideration that are constrained and any amounts collected on behalf of third parties. The transaction price may include fixed amounts, variable amounts, or both.
CellFormula_English: 'When a performance obligation is satisfied, revenue is recognised as the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the performance obligation, but excluding estimates of variable consideration that are constrained and any amounts collected on behalf of third parties. The transaction price may include fixed amounts, variable amounts, or both.

CellValue_English: The company allocates the transaction price to each performance obligation (or distinct good or service) in an amount that depicts the amount of consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring the promised goods or services to the customer.
CellFormula_English: 'The company allocates the transaction price to each performance obligation (or distinct good or service) in an amount that depicts the amount of consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring the promised goods or services to the customer.

CellValue_English: The company recognises as an asset the incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer if the company expects to recover those costs.
CellFormula_English: 'The company recognises as an asset the incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer if the company expects to recover those costs.

CellValue_English: When either party to a contract has performed, the company presents the contract in the statement of financial position as a contract asset or a contract liability, depending on the relationship between the company's performance and the customer's payment. The company presents any unconditional rights to consideration separately as a receivable.

Until "&TEXT(PriorYearEndDate,"d mmmm yyyy")&", the group classified foreign currency options as held-for-trading derivatives and accounted for them at fair value through profit or loss."

CellValue_English: Revenue from sale of [goods] is recognised at the point in time when control of the asset is transferred to the customer, generally on delivery of the [goods]. The normal credit term is [30 to 90] days upon delivery.

CellValue_English: The company considers whether there are other promises in the contract that are separate performance obligations to which a portion of the transaction price needs to be allocated (e.g., warranties, customer loyalty points). In determining the transaction price for the sale of [goods], the company considers the effects of variable consideration, the existence of significant financing components, non-cash consideration, and consideration payable to the customer (if any).
CellFormula_English: 'The company considers whether there are other promises in the contract that are separate performance obligations to which a portion of the transaction price needs to be allocated (e.g., warranties, customer loyalty points). In determining the transaction price for the sale of [goods], the company considers the effects of variable consideration, the existence of significant financing components, non-cash consideration, and consideration payable to the customer (if any).

CellValue_English: Variable consideration
CellFormula_English: 'Variable consideration

CellValue_English: If the consideration in a contract includes a variable amount, the company estimates the amount of consideration to which it will be entitled in exchange for transferring the goods to the customer. The variable consideration is estimated at contract inception and constrained until it is highly probable that a significant revenue reversal in the amount of cumulative revenue recognised will not occur when the associated uncertainty with the variable consideration is subsequently resolved. Some contracts for the sale of [goods] provide customers with a right of return and volume rebates. The rights of return and volume rebates give rise to variable consideration.
CellFormula_English: 'If the consideration in a contract includes a variable amount, the company estimates the amount of consideration to which it will be entitled in exchange for transferring the goods to the customer. The variable consideration is estimated at contract inception and constrained until it is highly probable that a significant revenue reversal in the amount of cumulative revenue recognised will not occur when the associated uncertainty with the variable consideration is subsequently resolved. Some contracts for the sale of [goods] provide customers with a right of return and volume rebates. The rights of return and volume rebates give rise to variable consideration.

CellValue_English: Rights of return
CellFormula_English: 'Rights of return

CellValue_English: Certain contracts provide a customer with a right to return the goods within a specified period. The company uses the expected value method to estimate the goods that will not be returned because this method best predicts the amount of variable consideration to which the company will be entitled. The requirements in IFRS 15 on constraining estimates of variable consideration are also applied in order to determine the amount of variable consideration that can be included in the transaction price. For goods that are expected to be returned, instead of revenue, the company recognises a refund liability. A right of return asset (and corresponding adjustment to cost of sales) is also recognised for the right to recover products from a customer.
CellFormula_English: '="Before "&TEXT(YearStartDate,"d mmmm yyyy")&", the company designated all of the forward contracts as hedging instrument. Any gains or losses arising from changes in the fair value of derivatives were taken directly to profit or loss,"&" except for the effective portion of cash flow hedges, which were recognised in OCI and later reclassified to profit or loss when the hedge item affects profit or loss."

CellValue_English: Volume rebates
CellFormula_English: 'Volume rebates

CellValue_English: The company provides retrospective volume rebates to certain customers once the quantity of products purchased during the period exceeds a threshold specified in the contract. Rebates are offset against amounts payable by the customer. To estimate the variable consideration for the expected future rebates, the company applies the most likely amount method for contracts with a single-volume threshold and the expected value method for contracts with more than one volume threshold. The selected method that best predicts the amount of variable consideration is primarily driven by the number of volume thresholds contained in the contract. The company then applies the requirements on constraining estimates of variable consideration and recognises a refund liability for the expected future rebates.
CellFormula_English: 'The company provides retrospective volume rebates to certain customers once the quantity of products purchased during the period exceeds a threshold specified in the contract. Rebates are offset against amounts payable by the customer. To estimate the variable consideration for the expected future rebates, the company applies the most likely amount method for contracts with a single-volume threshold and the expected value method for contracts with more than one volume threshold. The selected method that best predicts the amount of variable consideration is primarily driven by the number of volume thresholds contained in the contract. The company then applies the requirements on constraining estimates of variable consideration and recognises a refund liability for the expected future rebates.

CellValue_English: Significant financing component
CellFormula_English: 'Significant financing component

CellValue_English: Generally, the company receives short-term advances from its customers. Using the practical expedient in IFRS 15, the company does not adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of a significant financing component if it expects, at contract inception, that the period between the transfer of the promised good or service to the customer and when the customer pays for that good or service will be one year or less.
CellFormula_English: 'Generally, the company receives short-term advances from its customers. Using the practical expedient in IFRS 15, the company does not adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of a significant financing component if it expects, at contract inception, that the period between the transfer of the promised good or service to the customer and when the customer pays for that good or service will be one year or less.

CellValue_English: The company also receives long-term advances from customers for the sale of customised [goods]. The transaction price for such contracts is discounted, using the rate that would be reflected in a separate financing transaction between the company and its customers at contract inception, to take into consideration the significant financing component.
CellFormula_English: 'The company also receives long-term advances from customers for the sale of customised [goods]. The transaction price for such contracts is discounted, using the rate that would be reflected in a separate financing transaction between the company and its customers at contract inception, to take into consideration the significant financing component.

CellValue_English: Non-cash consideration
CellFormula_English: 'Non-cash consideration

CellValue_English: The company received [include details of non-cash considerations received] from certain customers to be used in manufacturing [goods] to be sold to them. The fair value of such non-cash consideration received from the customer is included in the transaction price and measured when the company obtains control of the [non-cash considerations].
CellFormula_English: 'The company received [include details of non-cash considerations received] from certain customers to be used in manufacturing [goods] to be sold to them. The fair value of such non-cash consideration received from the customer is included in the transaction price and measured when the company obtains control of the [non-cash considerations].

CellValue_English: The company applies the requirements of IFRS 13 Fair Value Measurement in measuring the fair value of the non-cash consideration. If the fair value cannot be reasonably estimated, the non-cash consideration is measured indirectly by reference to the stand-alone selling price of the [goods].
CellFormula_English: 'The company applies the requirements of IFRS 13 Fair Value Measurement in measuring the fair value of the non-cash consideration. If the fair value cannot be reasonably estimated, the non-cash consideration is measured indirectly by reference to the stand-alone selling price of the [goods].

CellValue_English: Consideration payable to a customer
CellFormula_English: 'Consideration payable to a customer

CellValue_English: Consideration payable to a customer includes cash amounts that the company pays, or expects to pay, to the customer. The consideration payable to a customer is accounted for as a reduction of the transaction price unless the payment to the customer is in exchange for a distinct good or service that the customer transfers to the company.
CellFormula_English: 'Consideration payable to a customer includes cash amounts that the company pays, or expects to pay, to the customer. The consideration payable to a customer is accounted for as a reduction of the transaction price unless the payment to the customer is in exchange for a distinct good or service that the customer transfers to the company.

CellValue_English: Warranty obligations  (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Warranty obligations  (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: The company typically provides warranties for general repairs of defects that existed at the time of sale, as required by law. These assurance-type warranties are accounted for under IAS 37 Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets.
CellFormula_English: 'The company typically provides warranties for general repairs of defects that existed at the time of sale, as required by law. These assurance-type warranties are accounted for under IAS 37 Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets.

CellValue_English: The company provides a one-year warranty beyond fixing defects that existed at the time of sale. These service-type warranties are sold either separately or bundled together with the sale of [goods]. Contracts for bundled sales of [goods] and a service-type warranty comprise two performance obligations because the promises to transfer the [goods] and to provide the service-type warranty are capable of being distinct. Using the relative stand-alone selling price method, a portion of the transaction price is allocated to the service-type warranty and recognised as a contract liability. Revenue is recognised over the period in which the service-type warranty is provided based on the time elapsed.
CellFormula_English: 'The company provides a one-year warranty beyond fixing defects that existed at the time of sale. These service-type warranties are sold either separately or bundled together with the sale of [goods]. Contracts for bundled sales of [goods] and a service-type warranty comprise two performance obligations because the promises to transfer the [goods] and to provide the service-type warranty are capable of being distinct. Using the relative stand-alone selling price method, a portion of the transaction price is allocated to the service-type warranty and recognised as a contract liability. Revenue is recognised over the period in which the service-type warranty is provided based on the time elapsed.

CellValue_English: Loyalty points programme (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Loyalty points programme (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: The company has a loyalty points programme, [include name of programme], which allows customers to accumulate points that can be redeemed for free products. The loyalty points give rise to a separate performance obligation as they provide a material right to the customer. A portion of the transaction price is allocated to the loyalty points awarded to customers based on relative stand-alone selling price and recognised as a contract liability until the points are redeemed. Revenue is recognised upon redemption of products by the customer.
CellFormula_English: 'The company has a loyalty points programme, [include name of programme], which allows customers to accumulate points that can be redeemed for free products. The loyalty points give rise to a separate performance obligation as they provide a material right to the customer. A portion of the transaction price is allocated to the loyalty points awarded to customers based on relative stand-alone selling price and recognised as a contract liability until the points are redeemed. Revenue is recognised upon redemption of products by the customer.

CellValue_English: When estimating the stand-alone selling price of the loyalty points, the company considers the likelihood that the customer will redeem the points. The company updates its estimates of the points that will be redeemed on a [quarterly] basis and any adjustments to the contract liability balance are charged against revenue.
CellFormula_English: 'When estimating the stand-alone selling price of the loyalty points, the company considers the likelihood that the customer will redeem the points. The company updates its estimates of the points that will be redeemed on a [quarterly] basis and any adjustments to the contract liability balance are charged against revenue.

CellValue_English: [Installation] services (customise according to business)
CellFormula_English: '[Installation] services (customise according to business)

CellValue_English: The company provides [installation] services that are either sold separately or bundled together with the sale of [goods] to a customer. The [installation] services can be obtained from other providers and do not significantly customise or modify the [goods].
CellFormula_English: 'The company provides [installation] services that are either sold separately or bundled together with the sale of [goods] to a customer. The [installation] services can be obtained from other providers and do not significantly customise or modify the [goods].

CellValue_English: Contracts for bundled sales of [goods] and [installation] services are comprised of two performance obligations because the promises to transfer [goods] and provide [installation] services are capable of being distinct and separately identifiable. Accordingly, the company allocates the transaction price based on the relative stand-alone selling prices of the [goods] and [installation] services.
CellFormula_English: 'Contracts for bundled sales of [goods] and [installation] services are comprised of two performance obligations because the promises to transfer [goods] and provide [installation] services are capable of being distinct and separately identifiable. Accordingly, the company allocates the transaction price based on the relative stand-alone selling prices of the [goods] and [installation] services.

CellValue_English: The company recognises revenue from [installation] services over time, using an input method to measure progress towards complete satisfaction of the service, because the customer simultaneously receives and consumes the benefits provided by the company. Revenue from the sale of [goods] are recognised at a point in time, generally upon delivery of the [goods].
CellFormula_English: 'The company recognises revenue from [installation] services over time, using an input method to measure progress towards complete satisfaction of the service, because the customer simultaneously receives and consumes the benefits provided by the company. Revenue from the sale of [goods] are recognised at a point in time, generally upon delivery of the [goods].

CellValue_English: Procurement services  (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Procurement services  (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: The company has contracts with customers to acquire, on their behalf, [include details of goods acquired on behalf of customer]. The company is acting as an agent in these arrangements.
CellFormula_English: 'The company has contracts with customers to acquire, on their behalf, [include details of goods acquired on behalf of customer]. The company is acting as an agent in these arrangements.

CellValue_English: When another party is involved in providing goods or services to its customer, the company determines whether it is a principal or an agent in these transactions by evaluating the nature of its promise to the customer. The company is a principal and records revenue on a gross basis if it controls the promised goods or services before transferring them to the customer. However, if the company's role is only to arrange for another entity to provide the goods or services, then the company is an agent and will need to record revenue at the net amount that it retains for its agency services.
CellFormula_English: 'When another party is involved in providing goods or services to its customer, the company determines whether it is a principal or an agent in these transactions by evaluating the nature of its promise to the customer. The company is a principal and records revenue on a gross basis if it controls the promised goods or services before transferring them to the customer. However, if the company's role is only to arrange for another entity to provide the goods or services, then the company is an agent and will need to record revenue at the net amount that it retains for its agency services.

CellValue_English: Construction of [properties] (customise according to business)
CellFormula_English: 'Construction of [properties] (customise according to business)

CellValue_English: The company constructs and sells [properties] under long-term contracts with customers. Such contracts are entered into before construction of the [properties] begins. Under the terms of the contracts, the company is contractually restricted from redirecting the properties to another customer and has an enforceable right to payment for work done. Revenue from construction of [properties] is therefore recognised over time on a cost–to–cost method, i.e. based on the proportion of contract costs incurred for work performed to date relative to the estimated total contract costs. The [directors] consider that this input method is an appropriate measure of the progress towards complete satisfaction of these performance obligations under IFRS 15.
CellFormula_English: 'The company constructs and sells [properties] under long-term contracts with customers. Such contracts are entered into before construction of the [properties] begins. Under the terms of the contracts, the company is contractually restricted from redirecting the properties to another customer and has an enforceable right to payment for work done. Revenue from construction of [properties] is therefore recognised over time on a cost–to–cost method, i.e. based on the proportion of contract costs incurred for work performed to date relative to the estimated total contract costs. The [directors] consider that this input method is an appropriate measure of the progress towards complete satisfaction of these performance obligations under IFRS 15.

CellValue_English: The company becomes entitled to invoice customers for construction of [properties] based on achieving a series of performance-related milestones. When a particular milestone is reached the customer is sent a relevant statement of work signed by a third party assessor and an invoice for the related milestone payment. The company will previously have recognised a contract asset for any work performed. Any amount previously recognised as a contract asset is reclassified to trade receivables at the point at which it is invoiced to the customer. If the milestone payment exceeds the revenue recognised to date under the cost–to–cost method then the company recognises a contract liability for the difference. There is not considered to be a significant financing component in construction contracts with customers as the period between the recognition of revenue under the cost–to–cost method and the milestone payment is always less than one year.
CellFormula_English: 'The company becomes entitled to invoice customers for construction of [properties] based on achieving a series of performance-related milestones. When a particular milestone is reached the customer is sent a relevant statement of work signed by a third party assessor and an invoice for the related milestone payment. The company will previously have recognised a contract asset for any work performed. Any amount previously recognised as a contract asset is reclassified to trade receivables at the point at which it is invoiced to the customer. If the milestone payment exceeds the revenue recognised to date under the cost–to–cost method then the company recognises a contract liability for the difference. There is not considered to be a significant financing component in construction contracts with customers as the period between the recognition of revenue under the cost–to–cost method and the milestone payment is always less than one year.

CellValue_English: Contract assets
CellFormula_English: 'Contract assets

CellValue_English: A contract asset is the right to consideration in exchange for goods or services transferred to the customer. If the company performs by transferring goods or services to a customer before the customer pays consideration or before payment is due, a contract asset is recognised for the earned consideration that is conditional.
CellFormula_English: 'A contract asset is the right to consideration in exchange for goods or services transferred to the customer. If the company performs by transferring goods or services to a customer before the customer pays consideration or before payment is due, a contract asset is recognised for the earned consideration that is conditional.

CellValue_English: Trade receivables
CellFormula_English: '=Note_Header_Prepay&" consist of various payments that have been made in advance for goods and services to be received in future. "&Note_Header_Prepay&" are measured at amortised cost, and are derecognised when the goods and services to which the prepayment relate have been received."

CellValue_English: A receivable represents the company's right to an amount of consideration that is unconditional (i.e., only the passage of time is required before payment of the consideration is due).
CellFormula_English: 'A receivable represents the company's right to an amount of consideration that is unconditional (i.e., only the passage of time is required before payment of the consideration is due).

CellValue_English: Contract liabilities
CellFormula_English: 'Contract liabilities

CellValue_English: A contract liability is the obligation to transfer goods or services to a customer for which the company has received consideration (or an amount of consideration is due) from the customer. If a customer pays consideration before the company transfers goods or services to the customer, a contract liability is recognised when the payment is made or the payment is due (whichever is earlier). Contract liabilities are recognised as revenue when the company performs under the contract.
CellFormula_English: 'A contract liability is the obligation to transfer goods or services to a customer for which the company has received consideration (or an amount of consideration is due) from the customer. If a customer pays consideration before the company transfers goods or services to the customer, a contract liability is recognised when the payment is made or the payment is due (whichever is earlier). Contract liabilities are recognised as revenue when the company performs under the contract.

CellValue_English: Assets and liabilities arising from rights of return
CellFormula_English: 'Assets and liabilities arising from rights of return

CellValue_English: Right of return assets  (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Right of return assets  (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: Right of return asset represents the company's right to recover the goods expected to be returned by customers. The asset is measured at the former carrying amount of the inventory, less any expected costs to recover the goods, including any potential decreases in the value of the returned goods. The company updates the measurement of the asset recorded for any revisions to its expected level of returns, as well as any additional decreases in the value of the returned products.
CellFormula_English: 'Right of return asset represents the company's right to recover the goods expected to be returned by customers. The asset is measured at the former carrying amount of the inventory, less any expected costs to recover the goods, including any potential decreases in the value of the returned goods. The company updates the measurement of the asset recorded for any revisions to its expected level of returns, as well as any additional decreases in the value of the returned products.

CellValue_English: Refund liabilities  (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Refund liabilities  (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: A refund liability is the obligation to refund some or all of the consideration received (or receivable) from the customer and is measured at the amount the company ultimately expects it will have to return to the customer. The company updates its estimates of refund liabilities (and the corresponding change in the transaction price) at the end of each reporting period. Refer to above accounting policy on variable consideration.
CellFormula_English: 'A refund liability is the obligation to refund some or all of the consideration received (or receivable) from the customer and is measured at the amount the company ultimately expects it will have to return to the customer. The company updates its estimates of refund liabilities (and the corresponding change in the transaction price) at the end of each reporting period. Refer to above accounting policy on variable consideration.

CellValue_English: Cost to obtain a contract (only include if applicable)
CellFormula_English: 'Cost to obtain a contract (only include if applicable)

CellValue_English: The company pays sales commission to its employees for each contract that they obtain for bundled sales of [goods] and [installation] services. The company has elected to apply the optional practical expedient for costs to obtain a contract which allows the company to immediately expense sales commissions (included under employee benefits and part of cost of sales) because the amortisation period of the asset that the company otherwise would have used is one year or less.
CellFormula_English: 'The company pays sales commission to its employees for each contract that they obtain for bundled sales of [goods] and [installation] services. The company has elected to apply the optional practical expedient for costs to obtain a contract which allows the company to immediately expense sales commissions (included under employee benefits and part of cost of sales) because the amortisation period of the asset that the company otherwise would have used is one year or less.

CellValue_English: Levies
CellFormula_English: 'Levies

CellValue_English: The ordinary levies receivable are accounted for on a straight-line basis over the financial year and decided amongst the directors on a participation quota basis. The annual ordinary levies are agreed and approved by the directors at the company's annual general meeting. Interest is recognised, in profit or loss, using the effective interest rate method. Interest on arrear levy contributions is recognised in terms of prescribed management rule 21(3)(c).
CellFormula_English: 'The ordinary levies receivable are accounted for on a straight-line basis over the financial year and decided amongst the directors on a participation quota basis. The annual ordinary levies are agreed and approved by the directors at the company's annual general meeting. Interest is recognised, in profit or loss, using the effective interest rate method. Interest on arrear levy contributions is recognised in terms of prescribed management rule 21(3)(c).

CellValue_English: Employee benefits
CellFormula_English: 'Employee benefits

CellValue_English: Employee benefits are all forms of consideration given by an entity in exchange for services rendered by employees or for the termination of employment.
CellFormula_English: 'Employee benefits are all forms of consideration given by an entity in exchange for services rendered by employees or for the termination of employment.

CellValue_English: Short-term employee benefits are employee benefits (other than termination benefits) that are expected to be settled wholly before twelve months after the end of the annual reporting period in which the employees render the related service.
CellFormula_English: 'Short-term employee benefits are employee benefits (other than termination benefits) that are expected to be settled wholly before twelve months after the end of the annual reporting period in which the employees render the related service.

CellValue_English: Post-employment benefits are employee benefits (other than termination benefits and short-term employee benefits) that are payable after the completion of employment.
CellFormula_English: 'Post-employment benefits are employee benefits (other than termination benefits and short-term employee benefits) that are payable after the completion of employment.

CellValue_English: Other long-term employee benefits are all employee benefits other than short-term employee benefits, post-employment benefits and termination benefits.
CellFormula_English: 'Other long-term employee benefits are all employee benefits other than short-term employee benefits, post-employment benefits and termination benefits.

CellValue_English: Termination benefits are employee benefits provided in exchange for the termination of an employee's employment as a result of either:
CellFormula_English: 'Termination benefits are employee benefits provided in exchange for the termination of an employee's employment as a result of either:

CellValue_English: Short-term employee benefits
CellFormula_English: 'Short-term employee benefits

CellValue_English: Compensation paid to employees for the rendering of services are recognised at the undiscounted amount paid or expected to be paid in the accounting period in which the services were rendered.
CellFormula_English: 'Compensation paid to employees for the rendering of services are recognised at the undiscounted amount paid or expected to be paid in the accounting period in which the services were rendered.

CellValue_English: Where employees accumulate entitlement for paid absences, an expense is recognised as the additional amount that the entity expects to pay as a result of the unused entitlement that has accumulated at the end of the reporting period. In the case of non-accumulating paid absences, the expense is recognised only when the absences occur.
CellFormula_English: 'Where employees accumulate entitlement for paid absences, an expense is recognised as the additional amount that the entity expects to pay as a result of the unused entitlement that has accumulated at the end of the reporting period. In the case of non-accumulating paid absences, the expense is recognised only when the absences occur.

CellValue_English: The expected cost of profit-sharing and bonus payments are recognised when there is a present legal or constructive obligation to make such payments as a result of past events, and a reliable estimate of the obligation can be made. A present obligation exists when there is no realistic alternative but to make the payments.
CellFormula_English: 'The expected cost of profit-sharing and bonus payments are recognised when there is a present legal or constructive obligation to make such payments as a result of past events, and a reliable estimate of the obligation can be made. A present obligation exists when there is no realistic alternative but to make the payments.

CellValue_English: Defined contribution plans
CellFormula_English: 'Defined contribution plans

CellValue_English: Defined contribution plans are post-employment benefit plans under which an entity pays fixed contributions into a separate entity (a fund) and will have no legal or constructive obligation to pay further contributions if the fund does not hold sufficient assets to pay all employee benefits relating to employee service in the current and prior periods.
CellFormula_English: 'Defined contribution plans are post-employment benefit plans under which an entity pays fixed contributions into a separate entity (a fund) and will have no legal or constructive obligation to pay further contributions if the fund does not hold sufficient assets to pay all employee benefits relating to employee service in the current and prior periods.

CellValue_English: When an employee has rendered service to an entity during a period, the contribution payable to a defined contribution plan in exchange for that service is recognised:
CellFormula_English: 'When an employee has rendered service to an entity during a period, the contribution payable to a defined contribution plan in exchange for that service is recognised:

CellValue_English: Defined benefit plans
CellFormula_English: 'Defined benefit plans

CellValue_English: Defined benefit plans are post-employment benefit plans other than defined contribution plans.
CellFormula_English: 'Defined benefit plans are post-employment benefit plans other than defined contribution plans.

CellValue_English: For defined benefit plans, the cost of providing benefits is determined using the projected unit cost method, with actuarial valuations being carried out at the end of each period. Remeasurement comprising actuarial gains and losses, the effect of changes to the asset ceiling, and the return on plan assets is reflected immediately in the statement of financial position with a charge or credit recognised in other comprehensive income in the period in which they occur. Remeasurement recognised in other comprehensive income is reflected immediately in retained earnings and will not be reclassified to profit or loss. Past service cost is recognised in profit or loss in the period of a plan amendment. Net interest calculated by applying the discount rate at the beginning of the period to the net defined benefit liability or asset. Defined benefit costs are categorised as follows:
CellFormula_English: 'For defined benefit plans, the cost of providing benefits is determined using the projected unit cost method, with actuarial valuations being carried out at the end of each period. Remeasurement comprising actuarial gains and losses, the effect of changes to the asset ceiling, and the return on plan assets is reflected immediately in the statement of financial position with a charge or credit recognised in other comprehensive income in the period in which they occur. Remeasurement recognised in other comprehensive income is reflected immediately in retained earnings and will not be reclassified to profit or loss. Past service cost is recognised in profit or loss in the period of a plan amendment. Net interest calculated by applying the discount rate at the beginning of the period to the net defined benefit liability or asset. Defined benefit costs are categorised as follows:

CellValue_English: The first two components of defined benefit costs are presented in profit or loss in the line item other operating expenses. Curtailment gains and losses are accounted for as past service costs.
CellFormula_English: 'The first two components of defined benefit costs are presented in profit or loss in the line item other operating expenses. Curtailment gains and losses are accounted for as past service costs.

CellValue_English: The retirement benefit obligation recognised in the statement of financial position represents the actual deficit or surplus in the defined benefit plans. Any surplus resulting from this calculation is limited to the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of refunds from the plans or reductions in future contributions to the plans.
CellFormula_English: 'The retirement benefit obligation recognised in the statement of financial position represents the actual deficit or surplus in the defined benefit plans. Any surplus resulting from this calculation is limited to the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of refunds from the plans or reductions in future contributions to the plans.

CellValue_English: Termination benefits
CellFormula_English: 'Termination benefits

CellValue_English: A liability for termination benefit is recognised at the earlier of when the offer can no longer be withdrawn and when the related restructuring costs are recognised.
CellFormula_English: 'A liability for termination benefit is recognised at the earlier of when the offer can no longer be withdrawn and when the related restructuring costs are recognised.

CellValue_English: Government grants
CellFormula_English: 'Government grants

CellValue_English: Government grants are assistance by government in the form of transfers of resources to an entity in return for past or future compliance with certain conditions relating to the operating activities of the company. They exclude those forms of government assistance which cannot reasonably have a value placed upon them and transactions with government which cannot be distinguished from the normal trading transactions of the company.
CellFormula_English: 'Government grants are assistance by government in the form of transfers of resources to an entity in return for past or future compliance with certain conditions relating to the operating activities of the company. They exclude those forms of government assistance which cannot reasonably have a value placed upon them and transactions with government which cannot be distinguished from the normal trading transactions of the company.

CellValue_English: Government grants, including non-monetary grants at fair value, are not recognised until there is reasonable assurance that:
CellFormula_English: 'Government grants, including non-monetary grants at fair value, are not recognised until there is reasonable assurance that:

CellValue_English: Government grants are recognised in profit or loss on a systematic basis over the periods in which the related costs for which the grants are intended to compensate are expensed.
CellFormula_English: 'Government grants are recognised in profit or loss on a systematic basis over the periods in which the related costs for which the grants are intended to compensate are expensed.

CellValue_English: A government grant that becomes receivable as compensation for expenses or losses already incurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the company with no future related costs are recognised in profit or loss of the period in which it becomes receivable.
CellFormula_English: 'A government grant that becomes receivable as compensation for expenses or losses already incurred or for the purpose of giving immediate financial support to the company with no future related costs are recognised in profit or loss of the period in which it becomes receivable.

CellValue_English: Non-monetary grants are measured at fair value of the non-monetary asset and both the grant and asset are recognised at that fair value. An alternative course that is sometimes followed is to record both asset and grant at a nominal amount.
CellFormula_English: 'Non-monetary grants are measured at fair value of the non-monetary asset and both the grant and asset are recognised at that fair value. An alternative course that is sometimes followed is to record both asset and grant at a nominal amount.

CellValue_English: Government grants related to assets, including non-monetary grants at fair value are presented in the statement of financial position either by setting up the grant as deferred income or by deducting the grant in arriving at the carrying amount of the asset.
CellFormula_English: 'Government grants related to assets, including non-monetary grants at fair value are presented in the statement of financial position either by setting up the grant as deferred income or by deducting the grant in arriving at the carrying amount of the asset.

CellValue_English: Grants related to income are presented as part of profit or loss, either separately or under a general heading such as 'Other income'; alternatively, they are deducted in reporting the related expense.
CellFormula_English: 'Grants related to income are presented as part of profit or loss, either separately or under a general heading such as 'Other income'; alternatively, they are deducted in reporting the related expense.

CellValue_English: Repayment of a grant related to income is applied first against any unamortised deferred credit recognised in respect of the grant. To the extent that the repayment exceeds any such deferred credit, or when no deferred credit exists, the repayment is recognised immediately in profit or loss.
CellFormula_English: 'Repayment of a grant related to income is applied first against any unamortised deferred credit recognised in respect of the grant. To the extent that the repayment exceeds any such deferred credit, or when no deferred credit exists, the repayment is recognised immediately in profit or loss.

CellValue_English: Repayment of a grant related to an asset is recognised by increasing the carrying amount of the asset or reducing the deferred income balance by the amount repayable. The cumulative additional depreciation that would have been recognised in profit or loss to date in the absence of the grant is recognised immediately in profit or loss.
CellFormula_English: 'Repayment of a grant related to an asset is recognised by increasing the carrying amount of the asset or reducing the deferred income balance by the amount repayable. The cumulative additional depreciation that would have been recognised in profit or loss to date in the absence of the grant is recognised immediately in profit or loss.

CellValue_English: Where a loan is received from government at below market interest rate, the difference between the fair value of the loan and the amount received is recognised as a government grant.
CellFormula_English: 'Where a loan is received from government at below market interest rate, the difference between the fair value of the loan and the amount received is recognised as a government grant.

CellValue_English: Borrowing costs
CellFormula_English: 'Borrowing costs

CellValue_English: Borrowing costs are interest and other costs that an entity incurs in connection with the borrowing of funds.
CellFormula_English: 'Borrowing costs are interest and other costs that an entity incurs in connection with the borrowing of funds.

CellValue_English: A qualifying asset is an asset that necessarily takes a substantial period of time to get ready for its intended use or sale.
CellFormula_English: 'A qualifying asset is an asset that necessarily takes a substantial period of time to get ready for its intended use or sale.

CellValue_English: Borrowing costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are capitalised as part of the cost of that asset. Other borrowing costs are recognised as an expense in the period in which it occurred.
CellFormula_English: 'Borrowing costs that are directly attributable to the acquisition, construction or production of a qualifying asset are capitalised as part of the cost of that asset. Other borrowing costs are recognised as an expense in the period in which it occurred.

CellValue_English: Where funds are borrowed specifically for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset, the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalisation is the actual borrowing costs incurred on that borrowing during the period less any investment income on the temporary investment of those borrowings.
CellFormula_English: 'Where funds are borrowed specifically for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset, the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalisation is the actual borrowing costs incurred on that borrowing during the period less any investment income on the temporary investment of those borrowings.

CellValue_English: Where funds are borrowed generally and the entity uses the funds for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset, the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalisation will be calculated by applying a capitalisation rate to the costs incurred on the qualifying asset. The capitalisation rate is based on the weighted average of the borrowing rate applicable to all borrowings outstanding during the period, apart from borrowings made specifically for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset.
CellFormula_English: 'Where funds are borrowed generally and the entity uses the funds for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset, the amount of borrowing costs eligible for capitalisation will be calculated by applying a capitalisation rate to the costs incurred on the qualifying asset. The capitalisation rate is based on the weighted average of the borrowing rate applicable to all borrowings outstanding during the period, apart from borrowings made specifically for the purpose of obtaining a qualifying asset.

CellValue_English: Capitalised borrowing costs are limited to actual borrowing costs incurred during any period.
CellFormula_English: 'Capitalised borrowing costs are limited to actual borrowing costs incurred during any period.

CellValue_English: The capitalising of borrowing costs as part of the cost of a qualifying asset will begin on the commencement date. The commencement date for capitalisation is the date when all of the following conditions are met:
CellFormula_English: 'The capitalising of borrowing costs as part of the cost of a qualifying asset will begin on the commencement date. The commencement date for capitalisation is the date when all of the following conditions are met:

CellValue_English: Capitalisation of borrowing costs is suspended during extended periods in which active development of a qualifying asset is suspended.
CellFormula_English: 'Capitalisation of borrowing costs is suspended during extended periods in which active development of a qualifying asset is suspended.

CellValue_English: Capitalising borrowing costs is ceased when substantially all the activities necessary to prepare the qualifying asset for its intended use or sale are complete.
CellFormula_English: 'Capitalising borrowing costs is ceased when substantially all the activities necessary to prepare the qualifying asset for its intended use or sale are complete.

CellValue_English: When construction of a qualifying asset  is completed in parts and each part is capable of being used while construction continues on other parts, capitalising borrowing costs ceases when all the activities necessary to prepare that part for its intended use or sale has been substantially completed.
CellFormula_English: 'When construction of a qualifying asset  is completed in parts and each part is capable of being used while construction continues on other parts, capitalising borrowing costs ceases when all the activities necessary to prepare that part for its intended use or sale has been substantially completed.

As a minimum, the following are regarded as related parties of the reporting entity:

CellFormula_English: 'A related party transaction is a transfer of resources, services or obligations between a reporting entity and a related party, regardless of whether a price is charged.

CellValue_English: For the purposes of the current reporting period, ended 29 February 2020, management has assessed the COVID-19 global pandemic and related impacts on the Group's operations as being a non-adjusting post-balance sheet event, based on key events occurring after the Group's reporting date. These key events include the timing of the declaration of COVID-19 as a global pandemic by the World Health Organisation on 11 March 2020, as well as the announcement of COVID-19 related lockdowns directed by the Governments of key geographies in which the Group operates, commencing on 20 March 2020 in the UK and later in other trading markets. These key events occurred post the Group's reporting date, being 29 February 2020.

These key events include the timing of the declaration of COVID-19 as a global pandemic by the World Health Organisation on 11 March 2020, as well as the announcement of COVID-19 related lockdowns directed by the Governments of key geographies in which the Group operates, commencing on 20 March 2020 in the UK and later in other trading markets. These key events occurred post the Group's reporting date, being 29 February 2020.

Refer to Note 0 for disclosure of non-adjusting subsequent events.

CellValue_English: The Group has assessed the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the assumptions and significant judgements made in the valuation of items of property plant and equipment. Following the assessment of a number of factors considered in the Group's COVID response plan, the directors have determined that the anticipated impact of COVID will not have a lasting impact on the productivity of the Group's property, plant and equipment. Management has determined that the economic events that have transpired as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic are not an adjusting event (refer to note 0 Events after reporting period).

CellValue_English: Estimated impairment of goodwill
CellFormula_English: 'Estimated impairment of goodwill

CellValue_English: The company tests annually whether goodwill has suffered any impairment, in accordance with the accounting policy stated in note X. The recoverable amounts of cash-generating units have been determined based on value-in-use calculations. These calculations require the use of estimates (note X).
CellFormula_English: 'The company tests annually whether goodwill has suffered any impairment, in accordance with the accounting policy stated in note X. The recoverable amounts of cash-generating units have been determined based on value-in-use calculations. These calculations require the use of estimates (note X).

CellValue_English: An impairment charge of C4,650 arose in the wholesale CGU in Step-land (included in the Russian operating segment) during the course of the 2014 year, resulting in the carrying amount of the CGU being written down to its recoverable amount. If the budgeted gross margin used in the value-in-use calculation for the wholesale CGU in Step-land had been 10% lower than management's estimates at 31 December 2014 (for example, 45.5% instead of 55.5%), the company would have recognised a further impairment of goodwill by C100 and would need to reduce the carrying value of property, plant and equipment by C300.
CellFormula_English: 'An impairment charge of C4,650 arose in the wholesale CGU in Step-land (included in the Russian operating segment) during the course of the 2014 year, resulting in the carrying amount of the CGU being written down to its recoverable amount. If the budgeted gross margin used in the value-in-use calculation for the wholesale CGU in Step-land had been 10% lower than management's estimates at 31 December 2014 (for example, 45.5% instead of 55.5%), the company would have recognised a further impairment of goodwill by C100 and would need to reduce the carrying value of property, plant and equipment by C300.

CellValue_English: If the estimated cost of capital used in determining the pre-tax discount rate for the wholesale CGU in Step-land had been 1% higher than management's estimates (for example, 14.8% instead of 13.8%), the company would have recognised a further impairment against goodwill of C100 and would need to reduce the carrying value of property, plant and equipment by C200.
CellFormula_English: 'If the estimated cost of capital used in determining the pre-tax discount rate for the wholesale CGU in Step-land had been 1% higher than management's estimates (for example, 14.8% instead of 13.8%), the company would have recognised a further impairment against goodwill of C100 and would need to reduce the carrying value of property, plant and equipment by C200.

CellValue_English: The company is subject to income taxes in numerous jurisdictions. Significant judgement is required in determining the worldwide provision for income taxes. There are many transactions and calculations for which the ultimate tax determination is uncertain. The company recognises liabilities for anticipated tax audit issues based on estimates of whether additional taxes will be due. Where the final tax outcome of these matters is different from the amounts that were initially recorded, such differences will impact the current and deferred income tax assets and liabilities in the period in which such determination is made.
CellFormula_English: 'The company is subject to income taxes in numerous jurisdictions. Significant judgement is required in determining the worldwide provision for income taxes. There are many transactions and calculations for which the ultimate tax determination is uncertain. The company recognises liabilities for anticipated tax audit issues based on estimates of whether additional taxes will be due. Where the final tax outcome of these matters is different from the amounts that were initially recorded, such differences will impact the current and deferred income tax assets and liabilities in the period in which such determination is made.

CellValue_English: The company enters into contracts with its customers to acquire, on their behalf, [include details of goods] produced by foreign suppliers. Under these contracts, the company provides procurement services (i.e., coordinating the selection of suitable suppliers and managing the ordering and delivery of the imported [goods]). The company determined that it does not control the goods before they are transferred to customers, and it does not have the ability to direct the use of the [goods] or obtain benefits from the [goods]. The following factors indicate that the company does not control the goods before they are being transferred to customers. Therefore, the company determined that it is an agent in these contracts.

The company determined that it does not control the goods before they are transferred to customers, and it does not have the ability to direct the use of the [goods] or obtain benefits from the [goods]. The following factors indicate that the company does not control the goods before they are being transferred to customers. Therefore, the company determined that it is an agent in these contracts.
